lines.text: I kinda like the butler.
Well, it's just as easy to like a millionaire.
Did somebody ask you to sniff a little white powder?
Oh, gee, Eadie, doesn't this tropical air melt you down at all?
Sure it does. I'm human.
Then, why don't we take one day off and have some fun?
'Cause we're gonna be ladies.
Aw, I'm no lady! I'm just an old-fashioned home girl - like Mae West.
I bet you were an awful cute baby.
You couldn't prove it. My family never had money to waste on photographs.

[after flirting with the bellhop]
Well, it you can't afford to tip 'em, you have to be polite!
Polite?
We have every vase in the place.

[Correcting her]
Vaahzzz.
Very Well. We have every vaaaaahzzz in the plaaaaahzzz.

[At an elegant party]
Will you try for once in your life to be a lady?
If they wanted ladies, they'd be home with their wives.
What is this, blackmail?
Why, Mr. Paige, it's about Mr. Cousins. I only wanted to thank you for keeping my name out of the papers.
Oh, is that so? All that publicity might have gotten you ahead.
Oh, but I don't want to get ahead. Not in show business.
Oh, you don't?
No. A few years in the spotlight, if you make it, and when that's over you're nothing but a has-been for the rest of your life.
Oh, where did you pick up all this philosophy?
Being poor and going hungry.

[to Paige]
You always knew I was a good girl, didn't ya?

[Interrupting]
Get married and go into that later.
You want to scratch me off your list. I'm not a ladies' man.
Oh, Mr. Paige. Don't be such a pessimist.
You know those New York big shots aren't going to be down at the train to meet us.
No, but I'm going to meet them if I have to dynamite Park Avenue.
Atta girl!
[They shake hands]
I like him and he's got plenty of dough.
It isn't the money that counts. It's being together with somebody you can be crazy about. You think life with some moth-eaten millionaire'll be anything like the fun you and I could have?
I told you I'm not out for fun.
Listen, beautiful. You're wasting your time on Tom Paige.

[Smiling]
It's my time if I want to waste it.

[Showing her the magnificent ballroom in his mansion]
That chair... sat in by Napoleon. Those chandeliers were lit up by Louis XVI.
[Pointing to a chaise]
Lulled in by DuBarry.
You know this place is big enough for a six-day bicycle race.

[laughs]
Very clever.
Katherine, don't be ludicrous. How am I doin'?
Say, those Park Avenue words don't go with your hair.
Well, they better get used to it.
Oh, let me go. Tom, you can't do this to me!
Hey, listen, that gag of yours about being a good girl... that isn't on the level, is it?

[Teary-eyed]
Yes. Yes, it is.
Why, Eadie... I...
I love you so much, Tom. You can make me cheap and common like a million others; but, gee, I wish you wouldn't.

[Lifting a glass at a banquet in his honor]
Ladies and gentleman... I give you a toast. To understanding, to tolerance, to mutual consideration, to honor mellowed by generosity, to peace among all the nations of the earth.
Nobody ever believes I have ideals; but, I have and I'll show 'em I have.
I'm gonna be somebody!
You bet you are! Why, you'll have your name in lights up on Broadway and...
Oh, no, I won't. I don't kid myself. I know my singing and dancing won't get me anywhere. I'm gonna get married!
Married?
Yes and I'm gonna marry somebody that is somebody.
Eadie, I'm crazy about you. I'd let you into that party in a minute - if you'd only be a little friendly.
Why, I never meant to be unfriendly.
Will you go to supper with me after the party?
Why, yes, Mr. Miller.
That's the girl!
What's the idea of all the whoopee?
Why, just a celebration for a few of my friends.
Have you any reason to celebrate?

[Chuckles]
Why not, why not? We all have to play once in awhile, don't we?
I should think I'd be the last man in the world you'd come to for help.
You are.
Will you have a cigarette?
No, I never smoke.
No minor vices, eh?
Mr. Cousins, people always think showgirls are wild. But, take me, for instance. All the time I've been on Broadway, I'm just the same girl as when I left home.
You can have the best time of your life from now on!
Say, what are you doing? Making me a proposition?
Mm-hmm. I haven't got any job this morning. I wouldn't be nice to the boss.
Well, what was wrong with him?
Mr. Paige, I've done a lot of thinking and ever since I was a kid I've always known there was only one right thing for any girl to do. And that's get married!
Boy, take us right to the beach and am I going to make that old ocean sizzle!
Here you is, ladies.
Boy, you may wait.
Kitty! It costs me eighty-seven fifty to bring you down here as my chaperone and chaperone's don't go for doorman, understand?
I'm waiting to see Mr. Paige.
Well, I'm Mr. Paige.

[Disbelievingly]
Hmm, is that so? Well, I'm Mrs. Vanderbilt and this is Mrs. Astor. But she left her pet horse at home.
How do you do Mrs. Astor?
Well, well, who's gonna pay me?
Why? You're not gonna make a god out of money, are you?
Ha-ha. Okay, baby.
Mr. Paige! I don't even know this young man! I never saw him until today. He came out here without an invitation and made himself obnoxious. He's a vulgar vulgarian!
Every day for the last two weeks, you've given me the come-on and every night you bring on the frost.

[Dropping in on T.R. and Eadie]
Well, well, I've been looking all over Palm Beach for you. Mind if I join you?
Yes, we want to be alone.

[Sits down at their table]
Well, I don't blame you! Prettiest girl in Palm Beach. You ought to see her in a bathing suit!
I've got to go to Washington tonight with your Dad.
Dad's going to Washington?
Sure. Don't you know?
Know what?
Well, the big shots that have been hovering around here.
[to Eadie]
He doesn't know that T.R. may head the American delegation to the new Disarmament Conference.
Great scott, are they pulling another one of those?
Another one? Your Dad thinks he's the biggest thing since Benjamin Franklin!
Do you know how often I've seen you since you picked up that - blonde chiseler? Just twice. What do you mean by bringing a platinum cutie like that into a respectable club like this?
Wait till you get back to New York, Eadie, I'll show you some speed!
A lot of guys think they can buy you for a good meal - but, it's all the same thing. I been in spots like this before and I can take care of myself.
Go ahead, honey, and get it off your chest.
You've had everything all your life! You've been all over the world. You pal around with the best people, but, there's one thing you haven't learned yet!
What's that?
That other people have feelings too. I haven't had any education. All right! I look like a hotsy-totsy. All right! Nobody cared two hoots whether I amount to anything or not! All right! But I care!
Gee, you're swell.
Yeah, but not swell enough to marry. Now, open that door!
You're driving me cuckoo!
You can pick things like her up on any street corner.
Eadie grew up in joints. She earned her living in second-rate nightclubs. And she came through the whole thing - clean!
You really think she could make the grade?
I'm going to put that scheming little gold digger, that hooked my son, just where she belongs.
Oh, you'll get over Tom Paige. Why, I've been that way about a million guys.
home and kiddies.
I'm not afraid, not as long as I have you.
